elements.description: - tells the text input menu to check for user input and refresh the displayed text if necessary. In general, unless you want to temporarily disallow input, this command should be called every frame while the text input menu is open.

elements.name: CloseTextInput
elements.description: - closes the text input menu, releasing it for use by other scripts. Be sure to call this command when you are done getting input.

elements.name: InsertInInputText
elements.description: - inserts formatted text at the current cursor position in the text input menu, as long as doing so would not increase the length of the text beyond its maximum length.

elements.name: GetTextInputControlPressed
elements.description: - allows scripters to define custom controls for text input. Returns the scan code of the last key pressed in conjunction with the CTRL key, excluding those keys reserved for use by the text input menu. Once the code has been retrieved, subsequent calls to this command will return -1; it will also return -1 if no control has been pressed (similar to

elements.name: DeleteFromInputText
elements.description: - deletes a number of characters or words from the input text in the direction specified, beginning from the current cursor position. Note that an html tag is treated as both a word and a character (it is not possible to delete only part of a tag). Both optional parameters are false by default.

elements.name: GetTextInputCursorPos
elements.description: - returns the current position of the cursor as an index into the input string

elements.name: MoveTextInputCursor
elements.description: - moves the cursor a specified number of characters in the specified direction from its current position. Note that each html tag is treated as a single character.

elements.name: SetInputText
elements.description: - replaces any text which has been input by the user with the specified text and repositions the cursor to the specified position. If the specified position is invalid (e.g. greater than the length of the text, or inside an html tag), returns false without modifying the input text; otherwise returns true. For books, the text must be in an appropriate format - no invalid html tags should be present and the text must be prefixed with html of the format

elements.name: SetTextInputHandler
elements.description: - registers a function script to handle control-key combos pressed while the current text input menu is active. The function script should accept a single integer argument; when a key is pressed in conjunction with the Control key, that key's scan code will be passed to the function script. The script will not be informed of control-key combos which are handled by OBSE (for instance, ctrl+5 to change to font #5) unless the default controls have been disabled with SetTextInputDefaultControlsDisabled. The function script is unregistered when the text input menu is closed.

elements.name: SetTextInputDefaultControlsDisabled
elements.description: - sets whether or not OBSE responds to control-key combos it recognizes, such as ctrl+(number) for changing the font. While default controls are disabled, they will be passed to the function script registered with SetTextInputHandler or stored for retrieval using GetTextInputControlPressed. This setting is reset when the text input menu is closed.

elements.name: sv_Construct
elements.description: - constructs a string from a format string and set of variables and assigns the result to a string variable.
example: (nothing) sv_Construct formatString:string var1 var2 ... var20 variableToSet:string_var

elements.name: sv_Destruct
elements.description: - destroys a string variable, setting its value to zero and preventing its contents from being saved in the savegame. Two different syntaxes are supported: the first should be used in an assignment with no parameters, using the

elements.name: sv_Length
elements.description: - returns the number of characters in a string variable

elements.name: sv_Compare
elements.description: - compares a string to a formatted string. Performs a case-insensitive comparison by default. Returns 0 if the strings are equal, 1 if the string variable occurs alphabetically before the formatted string, -1 if the string variable occurs alphabetically after the formatted string, or -2 if the comparison fails.
example: (comparison:int) sv_Compare formatString:string var1 var2 ... var20 variable:string_var caseSensitive:bool

elements.name: sv_Erase
elements.description: - erases the specified number of characters from a string starting at the specified position. If omitted,

elements.name: sv_ToNumeric
elements.description: - attempts to convert the contents of a string variable to a number. Valid characters include digits, a leading sign, and an e to indicate scientific notation. Conversion halts at the first invalid character.

elements.name: sv_Find
elements.description: - returns the index of the first occurrence of a substring within a string variable, starting at the specified position and only including occurrences contained completely within the range [
example: (index:int) sv_Find subString:formatString formatVars source:string_var startPos:int searchLen:int caseSensitive:bool

elements.name: sv_Count
elements.description: - returns the number of occurrences of a substring within a string variable, using the same arguments as
example: (count:int) sv_Count subString:formatString formatVars source:string_var startPos:int searchLen:int

elements.name: sv_Replace
elements.description: - replaces occurrences of a string1 with string2 within a string variable. Both the text to replace and that with which to replace it are passed in a single format string separated by a pipe character as in "toReplace|replaceWith" (when calling from the console, use '@' in place of the pipe character). You can specify a range to search and case-sensitivity as in
example: (numReplaced:int) sv_Replace subString:formatString formatVars source:string_var startPos:int searchLen:int caseSensitive:bool numToReplace:int

elements.name: sv_Insert
elements.description: - inserts a substring into a string at the specified position, provided the position is less than the length of the string, or prepends it if no position is specified.

elements.name: sv_Split
elements.description: - given a string and a set of delimiters, returns an Array containing all the substrings separated by one or more of the delimiting characters. For example,

elements.name: GetKeyName
elements.description: - returns the name of a key given its DirectInput scan code

elements.name: AsciiToChar
elements.description: - returns the character associated with an ASCII code as a string

elements.name: NumToHex
elements.description: - returns a string representation of an integer in hexadecimal format. An optional

elements.name: sv_Percentify
elements.description: - Takes an input string and returns it with each '%' character replaced by two '%' characters. For instance, "100% gold" becomes "100%% gold" and "99.99%%" becomes "99.99%%%%". The argument can be any expression evaluating to a string value.

elements.name: sv_ToLower
elements.description: - returns the passed string with all characters converted to lowercase.

elements.name: sv_ToUpper
elements.description: - returns the passed string with all characters converted to uppercase.

elements.name: IsDigit
elements.description: - returns 1 if the character is a digit

elements.name: IsPunctuation
elements.description: - returns 1 if the character is punctuation

elements.name: IsUppercase
elements.description: - returns 1 if the character is an uppercase letter

elements.name: IsPrintable
elements.description: - returns 1 if the character is printable (not a non-printable control character)

elements.name: IsLetter
elements.description: - returns 1 if the character is alphabetic

elements.name: CharToASCII
elements.description: - returns the ASCII code of a character passed as a string. Additional characters in the string are ignored.

elements.name: ToUpper
elements.description: - returns the ASCII code of a character converted to uppercase

elements.name: ToLower
elements.description: - returns the ASCII code of a character converted to lowercase

elements.name: ToNumber
elements.description: - takes a string expression and attempts to convert it to a numeric value. By default the string is assumed to be in decimal notation containing digits, at most one decimal point, and an optional leading sign. If the string is prefixed with "0x" or the optional argument is non-zero, the string is interpreted in hexadecimal notation instead, with valid characters consisting of digits and the letters 'A' through 'F'. Returns 0 if the conversion fails.

elements.name: ar_Construct
elements.description: - creates a new array_var and assigns it to an array variable. Must be called within the context of an OBSE expression such as

elements.name: ar_Size
elements.description: - returns the number of elements in an array, or -1 if the array is not initialized. For Array-type variables the highest key in the array is equal to one less than the array's size. Must be called within the context of an OBSE expression. The array can be an array variable or an array element which contains an array.

elements.name: ar_Dump
elements.description: - for debugging purposes, prints the key and value of every element in an array to the console. Must be called within an OBSE expression.

elements.name: ar_DumpID
elements.description: - does the same as ar_Dump but accepts an array ID instead of an array_var. Provided as a convenience for debugging in the console.

elements.name: ar_Find
elements.description: - locates the first occurrence of the specified value within an array and returns the key associated with it. A range may optionally be specified using range notation, i.e.

elements.name: ar_Sort
elements.description: - attempts to sort the elements of an array in ascending or descending order and returns a new Array containing the elements in sorted order (keys associated with the elements are lost). In order to be sorted all elements of an array must be of the same type (strings, numbers, or objects). If this condition is not met an empty Array is returned. Strings are sorted alphabetically and case-insensitively, numbers are sorted numerically, and objects are sorted by formID. By default the elements are sorted in ascending order.

elements.name: ar_SortAlpha
elements.description: - sorts the elements of an array alphabetically in ascending or descending order and returns a new Array containing the elements in sorted order. Ordering is case-insensitive. Unlike

elements.name: ar_Copy
elements.description: - creates a copy of the keys and elements of the specified array. The resulting array is identical to the source array. If the source array contains other arrays, the copy will contain

elements.name: ar_DeepCopy
elements.description: - performs the same function as

elements.name: ar_First
elements.description: - returns the key of the first element in an array

elements.name: ar_Last
elements.description: - returns the key of the last element in an array

elements.name: ar_Next
elements.description: - returns the key of the element immediately following the passed key, or

elements.name: ar_Prev
elements.description: - returns the key of the element immediately preceding the passed key, or

elements.name: ar_BadNumericIndex
elements.description: - returns a constant representing an invalid numeric array index. Compare to the return value of commands returning an array key to determine if a valid key was returned.

elements.name: ar_BadStringIndex
elements.description: - as above, but for string array keys

elements.name: ar_Keys
elements.description: - returns an Array containing all of the keys of the source array

elements.name: ar_HasKey
elements.description: - returns true if the array has an element with the specified key

elements.name: ar_Null
elements.description: - returns an invalid array. This is useful if you wish to specify that a variable which previously referred to an array should no longer refer to any array.

elements.name: ar_List
elements.description: - Takes up to twenty arguments of any type and returns an Array containing those elements in the order in which they were passed. We recommend separating the values with commas (starting after the first argument).

elements.name: ar_Resize
elements.description: - resizes an Array-type array to be of the specified size. If the new size is smaller than the current size, elements at the end of the array are discarded. If the new size is larger, additional elements are appended to the array. By default these elements have the numeric value zero, but an optional argument can be used to specify the value with which to pad the array. Returns 1 if successful, 0 otherwise.

elements.name: ar_Insert
elements.description: - inserts a single element into an Array-type array at the specified index provided the index is not greater than the current size of the array. Elements above the index are shifted up by one index.

elements.name: ar_InsertRange
elements.description: - inserts a range of elements into an Array-type array at the specified index provided the index is not greater than the current size of the array. The range is passed as an Array. Each element of the range is inserted into the target Array in order. Elements above the insertion index are shifted up by the number of elements inserted.

elements.name: ar_Range
elements.description: - returns an Array of zero or more numbers ranging from

elements.name: ar_CustomSort
elements.description: - returns an Array sorted by calling the provided function script to perform comparison of elements. The function should be defined to take two array_var arguments. When it is called, the arguments will contain exactly one element each - the elements to be compared. It should return true if the first argument is less than the second argument, and true if it is greater than or equal to the second argument. You can define 'less', 'greater', and 'equal' in whatever way makes sense for you provided your definitions provide a definitive ordering of any set of values; otherwise the sort may never terminate. The optional third argument sorts the elements in reverse order.

elements.name: Let
elements.description: - The Let statement is OBSE's version of Oblivion's

elements.name: TestExpr
elements.description: - attempts to evaluate an expression, returning false if an error occurs during evaluation and true otherwise. This can be useful when checking if an array index is out of bounds or if an element exists with a given key, among other things.

elements.name: ToString
elements.description: - attempts to convert an expression to a string. For numeric expressions, the result is a string representation of the numeric value. For objects, it is the name of the object if available; otherwise it is the formID expressed in hexadecimal notation. For string expressions no conversion is necessary.

elements.name: TypeOf
elements.description: - returns a string representing the type of an expression. This is mainly useful for determining the type of an array element at run-time. Possible return values: "String", "Number", "Form", "Array", "StringMap", "Map".

elements.name: Function
elements.description: - a blocktype which precedes the body of a function. This blocktype is only valid within function scripts. A parameter list consisting of up to ten local variables used to hold arguments passed to the function must follow this keyword enclosed in curly braces; if the function takes no arguments the braces should be empty.

elements.name: SetFunctionValue
elements.description: - specifies the value to be returned from a function. Valid only within a

elements.name: Call
elements.description: - calls a user-defined function. Should be followed by a list of arguments matching the types expected by the function. If a calling reference is specified, commands within the function body will operate on that reference. Call returns whatever value is returned by the function.

elements.name: GetCallingScript
elements.description: - returns the script that called the currently executing function script. Returns nothing if the function script was not invoked by a

elements.name: SetEventHandler
elements.description: - registers a user-defined function as a handler for the specified event. If the function script returns a value, it will be ignored. Two optional arguments can be supplied as key::value pairs to filter events according to the target and/or object.

elements.name: RemoveEventHandler
elements.description: - removes the specified script as an event handler for the specified event. Two optional arguments can be supplied as key::value pairs to filter events according to the target and/or object. If both filters are omitted, all event handlers matching the script and event will be removed. If only one filter is omitted, all handlers matching the script, event, and the other filter will be removed. Returns true if at least one matching event handler was found and removed, false otherwise.

elements.name: GetCurrentEventName
elements.description: - When called from within an event handler, returns the name of the event currently being handled, as defined

elements.name: DispatchEvent
elements.description: - dispatches a user-defined event to any registered listeners. The eventName parameter specifies the event that occurred; this should be fairly unique to prevent event name clashes between different mods, but the event handler can also disambiguate name clashes by checking the name of the event sender if necessary. The optional second parameter is a StringMap containing any additional information about the event. When the event is dispatched, the array will also include the event name and the name of the sender. If omitted, the name of the sender is the filename from which the event originated; otherwise it matches the supplied third argument.

elements.name: RemoveMeIR
elements.description: - removes an inventory reference from its container, optionally transferring it to a different container, in much the same way as the vanilla RemoveMe command. The inventory reference becomes invalid once this command is called and should no longer be used. This command will not remove

elements.name: CopyIR
elements.description: - copies an inventory reference to the specified container. The calling object needn't be in a container and remains valid after the command is called. If the calling object is equipped, the copy will not be equipped.

elements.name: CreateTempRef
elements.description: - creates a temporary reference to the specified form. This reference does not exist in the gameworld or in a container, and remains valid for only one frame. It is mostly useful for creating a stack of one or more items to be added to a container with CopyIR

elements.name: GetInvRefsForItem
elements.description: - given a base inventory item, returns an Array of temporary references to stacks of that item inside the calling container.

elements.name: IsEquipped
elements.description: - returns true if the calling object is currently being worn

elements.name: GetLocalGravity
elements.description: - returns the acceleration due to gravity in the specified axis for the current cell. Unless SetLocalGravityVector has been used, the x and y components will always be zero.

elements.name: SetLocalGravity
elements.description: - sets the vertical acceleration due to gravity for the current cell. Negative values are the norm, causing objects to accelerate downward, but positive values are also acceptable. Changing the gravity for an exterior cell changes it for

elements.name: SetLocalGravityVector
elements.description: - sets the x, y, and z components of local acceleration due to gravity. This can be used to cause gravity to act in a non-vertical direction, which might be useful for simulating water currents.

elements.name: GetVelocity
elements.description: - returns the actor's current velocity in the specified axis.

elements.name: GetVerticalVelocity
elements.description: - returns the z component of the actor's current velocity.

elements.name: SetVelocity
elements.description: - sets the x, y, and z components of the actor's velocity. The change applies only to the current frame.

elements.name: SetVerticalVelocity
elements.description: - Sets the vertical velocity for an actor. This is primarily useful for actors who are jumping or falling. Positive values will cause the actor to move upwards, negative values will cause him to move downwards, and zero will prevent him from moving vertically for the current frame. On the subsequent frame, acceleration due to gravity will be applied to the new velocity. This means that if you set a falling actor's velocity to zero, on the next frame he will appear to accelerate as if he had just begun falling.
